Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: The pantry is stocked with kosher ingredients, and alternative snacks are readily available.
Story:
My younger sister, Leah, bounced into my room, her eyes bright with excitement. “Come on, we’re all going to Jake’s for pizza and games tonight! You have to come.” I could see how much it meant to her—she always wanted us to do things together, to feel like a real team. As her brother, I knew how important it was to show up, to be included, to build that trust and respect between us.

But my mind immediately jumped to the food. Jake’s place never had kosher options, and the last time I went, I ended up nibbling on a plain salad while everyone else devoured cheesy slices and pepperoni rolls. At home, our pantry was full of kosher snacks, and Mom always made sure I had something to eat. But out there, I’d have to either break the rules or sit awkwardly, feeling left out.

Leah was waiting for my answer, her hopefulness almost painful. I wanted to be the brother she could count on, but I also wanted to honor my Jewish values. The two parts of me pulled in opposite directions, and I felt the tension knotting in my chest as I tried to figure out what to say.
